Literature Review: The silkworm (Bombyx mori) has long been recognized as an economically significant insect and a valuable model organism for life science research. However, the sericulture industry faces a major challenge in the form of Bombyx mori nucleopolyhedrovirus (BmNPV) disease, which accounts for over 60% of the total losses caused by all silkworm diseases. This devastating impact has prompted extensive research into understanding the mechanisms of silkworm resistance to BmNPV and developing antiviral breeding strategies.The discovery of disease-resistant resources in 1989 marked a turning point in the field, inspiring researchers worldwide to search for resistance genes. Over the past two decades, significant progress has been made in identifying candidate genes and elucidating the molecular mechanisms underlying silkworm resistance to BmNPV.One of the primary approaches in studying silkworm resistance has been through genetic analysis. Researchers have employed various techniques, including quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping and genome-wide association studies (GWAS), to identify genomic regions associated with BmNPV resistance. For instance, Ito et al. (2008) conducted QTL analysis and identified several loci on chromosomes 1, 5, and 21 that were linked to BmNPV resistance. These findings provided a foundation for further investigation into specific genes within these regions.Building upon these genetic studies, researchers have focused on gene localization to pinpoint specific resistance genes. Xu et al. (2018) employed a combination of linkage analysis and RNA sequencing to identify a novel resistance gene, Bm64, located on chromosome 5. This gene was found to play a crucial role in inhibiting BmNPV replication and enhancing the survival rate of infected silkworms.The advent of multi-omics technologies has greatly accelerated the identification of candidate resistance genes and the elucidation of their functions. Transcriptomics studies have revealed differential gene expression patterns between resistant and susceptible silkworm strains upon BmNPV infection. For example, Feng et al. (2012) conducted a comprehensive transcriptome analysis and identified several genes involved in innate immunity, apoptosis, and cellular transport that were upregulated in resistant strains.Proteomics approaches have also contributed significantly to our understanding of silkworm resistance mechanisms. Wu et al. (2011) employed two-dimensional gel electrophoresis and mass spectrometry to identify proteins differentially expressed in resistant and susceptible silkworm strains. Their study revealed the involvement of proteins related to energy metabolism, protein synthesis, and stress response in BmNPV resistance.The interaction between the virus and its host is a critical aspect of understanding resistance mechanisms. Researchers have made significant strides in elucidating the molecular basis of virus-host interactions in the silkworm-BmNPV system. Jiang et al. (2012) demonstrated that the silkworm protein BmNPV-induced protein 1 (BmNPV-IP1) interacts with the viral protein IE1, inhibiting viral gene expression and replication. This discovery highlighted the importance of host factors in modulating viral infection and resistance.Recent advances in genetic modification techniques have opened up new avenues for enhancing silkworm resistance to BmNPV. RNA interference (RNAi) has emerged as a powerful tool for studying gene function and developing resistant strains. Jiang et al. (2017) successfully used RNAi to silence the expression of a viral gene, ie-1, resulting in increased resistance to BmNPV infection in transgenic silkworms.Furthermore, the application of CRISPR/Cas9 technology has revolutionized the field of silkworm breeding. Chen et al. (2020) employed CRISPR/Cas9 to create knockout mutants of the BmNPV receptor gene, BmNPCR, leading to enhanced resistance to viral infection. This groundbreaking study demonstrated the potential of genome editing in developing disease-resistant silkworm strains.While significant progress has been made in understanding silkworm resistance to BmNPV, several challenges remain. The complex nature of resistance mechanisms, involving multiple genes and pathways, necessitates a comprehensive approach to breeding resistant varieties. Additionally, the potential ecological impacts of genetically modified silkworms must be carefully evaluated before widespread implementation.In conclusion, the past two decades have witnessed remarkable advancements in our understanding of silkworm resistance to BmNPV. The integration of genetic analysis, multi-omics technologies, and molecular biology approaches has led to the identification of numerous candidate resistance genes and the elucidation of underlying mechanisms. These findings have paved the way for the development of disease-resistant silkworm varieties through hybrid breeding, RNAi, and genetic modification. As research in this field continues to evolve, it is anticipated that further insights into the molecular mechanisms of silkworm disease resistance will emerge, ultimately leading to more effective strategies for combating BmNPV and ensuring the sustainability of the sericulture industry.
